perturbation.changed_text:
(b) Each Seller agrees that for a period commencing on the Effective Date and ending ten years after the Closing Date (the “Non-Compete Period”), it shall not, other than solely through its direct or indirect ownership of Buyer’s capital stock or any other interests in Buyer, directly, or indirectly, including through or on behalf of a subsidiary, anywhere in the world, including India: (i) own, manage, operate or control any business which competes with any Combined Business or (ii) be or become a shareholder, partner, member or owner of any Person who is engaged in any Combined Business; provided, however that nothing in this Agreement shall:
(i) prohibit or restrict any Seller, directly or indirectly, from owning, as a passive investor, not more than one (1%) percent
collectively and in the aggregate of any class of outstanding publicly traded securities of any Person so engaged;
(ii) prohibit or restrict any Seller, directly or indirectly, from engaging in such Seller’s business as conducted on the Effective Date.
(iii) apply to or restrict any business of which a Seller acquires control after the Effective Date regardless of the acquired business net sales from product lines included within the definition of Company Business.
perturbation.explanation: The original contract specifies a two-year non-compete period and excludes India from the non-compete region. It also permits up to 5% passive investment. Changing the non-compete period to ten years, including India in the non-compete region, reducing passive investment allowance to 1%, and removing the net sales limit could render the clause overly broad and unreasonable under Pennsylvania law, which governs the agreement. Pennsylvania courts typically disfavor overly broad non-compete agreements, especially in duration and geographic scope. This change makes the restriction likely unenforceable.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Pennsylvania law regarding the reasonableness of non-compete agreements, particularly concerning duration, geographic scope, and legitimate business interests.

perturbation.changed_text: (d) Each Seller agrees that for a period commencing on the Effective Date and continuing indefinitely after the Closing Date (the “Non-Solicit Period”), each Seller shall not, directly or indirectly: (i) induce, solicit, recruit or attempt to persuade any employee of the Combined Business to terminate his or her employment with the Buyer or any of its subsidiaries, or (ii) solicit the employment of any of the employees of the Combined Business. Sellers shall be restricted from soliciting for employment or hiring former employees of Buyer or the Company (including their respective subsidiaries) regardless of when the employment was terminated by Buyer or the Company (including their respective subsidiaries) or soliciting employees of the Combined Business by any means.
perturbation.explanation: Pennsylvania law disfavors non-solicitation agreements that are unlimited in time. Removing the three-year limit and extending the non-solicitation obligation indefinitely is likely unenforceable under Pennsylvania law because it is an unreasonable restraint on trade and on an individual's ability to earn a living. By removing the exception for soliciting former employees and prohibiting general solicitations, the clause becomes even more overly restrictive, increasing the likelihood of unenforceability.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Pennsylvania law regarding the reasonableness of non-solicitation agreements, particularly concerning duration and scope.

perturbation.changed_text: (e) It is the intention of the parties that the covenants contained in this Section 1 shall be enforced to the maximum extent in time, area and degree of participation, regardless of any potentially conflicting laws or regulations. The parties agree that Section 1 shall be construed to extend infinitely in time and territory, irrespective of enforceability in any jurisdiction, and that the covenants contained in this Section 1 are not divisible or severable. This Section 1 shall be governed and construed to give maximum effect to its restrictive terms, overriding any principles of reasonableness or public policy.
perturbation.explanation: The original clause aims for maximum permissible enforcement. By changing the language to enforce Section 1 regardless of conflicting laws, overriding reasonableness and public policy, the clause becomes directly contradictory to established legal principles. Pennsylvania courts (and courts generally) will not enforce contract terms that are against public policy or violate statutory restrictions. This change effectively negates the principle of severability and the clause's original intention to comply with applicable law, making it directly contradict legal standards for contract enforceability.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Pennsylvania law and general contract law principles regarding public policy, reasonableness, severability, and the enforceability of contracts.
